awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Epidermal Sensor for Human Performance Assessment and Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a wearable sensor and analytical platform capable of non-invasively monitoring human health and athletic performance. This SBIR Phase 1 project will result in a miniaturized, durable wearable sensor that can be comfortably worn in any environment athletic or otherwise. The device will contain a novel suite of sensors capable of measuring health and performance related parameters. The analytical platform will continuously predict core body temperature, athletic performance, and optimal athletic training goals. The core body temperature prediction algorithm will provide an early warning when the core temperature approaches a dangerous level, which will mitigate the serious and growing risk of heat-related illness. The performance and optimal training prediction algorithms will provide training suggestions to achieve maximum performance growth. 
 
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the unmet technological and clinical need to integrate biomechanical, physiological, and thermoregulatory parameters into a single unobtrusive device and provide users with meaningful and actionable insight toward health and performance. The critical research objectives of this Phase 1 project are the development of: a comprehensive suite of sensors packaged into a durable and comfortable wearable device, a reliable and accurate core temperature prediction algorithm, performance and optimal workload prediction algorithms, and an integrated system providing clear and useful feedback to users regardless of medical or scientific knowledge. The hardware will be incorporated into a 0.75x0.75 inch form factor, continuously measure all parameters with medical grade accuracy, and achieve a minimum battery life of 90 hours. Algorithm development will leverage high-fidelity datasets, advanced signal processing, and custom deep learning architectures involving multivariate Long Short-Term Memory and feed forward neural networks to understand the non-linear, time dependent relationships between parameters and overall human performance and safety. These complex relationships will be distilled into an easily understandable and visually appealing user interface.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Athletes continually push the boundaries of human performance. Their drive to improve requires new methods and tools to optimize athletic training while minimizing the incidence of overexertion or heat related illness. The “push through” mentality adopted by traditional coaches and athletes paired with rising numbers of extreme heat days results in at least 9,000 cases of exertional heat related illness in high school athletes in the US alone per year. In endurance sports, 7% of marathon runners and 17% of cyclists in championship events suffer from heat related illness. Advanced wearable sensors paired with continuous predictive analytics have the potential to allow athletes to optimize their training while simultaneously improving their safety.

 

 Despite the growing usage of wearable technology to track basic physiological metrics and activities, most athletes still lack a method to optimize their training using objective data. Currently, athletes have to wear multiple devices, manually combine the data collected from these devices, and perform their own analytics. This process requires time, expertise, and teams of professionals which only the most elite athletes have access to. Even then, current techniques are unreliable or unproven. These deficiencies leave most athletes training based on arbitrary metrics, static training plans, or subjective feeling. Technology developed during the Phase I project will provide athletes with continuous, scientifically validated, actionable insights to improve their safety and train more efficiently. 

 

Over the course of the Phase I project, PrediCOR LLC has proven both the technical and commercial feasibility of advanced wearable sensors and predictive analytics to optimize athletic performance and mitigate the risk of heat related illness. The research and development conducted under the Phase I project has produced a comprehensive wearable device, the most accurate core temperature prediction algorithm commercially available, and vastly improved scientific understanding of human health and performance. 

 

 The device developed during the Phase I project is the first capable of continuously monitoring internal, external, and thermal parameters of an athlete and is miniaturized to an area approximately the size of a US quarter. The preliminary core temperature algorithm has surpassed the accuracy of all competitors that have been publicly studied, does not require additional manual inputs from users, and enables our mobile app to warn users when they are at risk of heat related illness. Highly accurate core temperature prediction paired with other thermal and mechanical measurements made by the device enabled the development of an energy expenditure model based on accepted principles of physics and thermodynamics. The translation of the metrics measured and calculated by the system into actionable feedback and workout recommendations for users is a vast improvement over the numeric results provided by current wearable devices and will provide a significant technical competitive advantage in the market. Continued R&D based on the results of this Phase I project will result in technology capable of actively improving the health of athletic users and ultimately the broader American public.


Last Modified: 08/17/2022
Modified by: Evan Davies
